2025-11-08T01:57:45.770469058Z       title: "Don't Fear",
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770473198Z       content: "<b>Toshinori Yagi</b> (ÂÖ´„ÇÑÊú®„Åé‰øä„Å®„ÅóÂÖ∏„ÅÆ„Çä Yagi Toshinori?), also known as All Might, is one of the main characters of My Hero Academia. He is the former No. 1 Pro Hero who bore the title of the world's Symbol of Peace.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770476768Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770480608Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770485179Z         "All Might was the eighth holder of the One For All Quirk after receiving it from Nana Shimura. He has since passed the torch onto Izuku Midoriya, whom he trained to be his successor. After using up all the embers of One For All to defeat All For One, All Might retired and ended his era as the world's greatest hero.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770488399Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770490509Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770493359Z         "He taught Foundational Hero Studies at U.A. High School, and now serves as the school's vice principal eight years after the Final War.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770495919Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770497989Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770500179Z         `His catchphrase is: "Don't Fear, I am Here"\n` +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770502319Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.7705044Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.77050736Z         'In his empowered form, All Might is a towering figure with a powerfully muscular and well-defined physique, resembling a classic Western comic book superhero. He has chiseled facial features, including a strong jawline, pronounced cheekbones, and bushy eyebrows. His short blond hair is swept backward, with two distinct tufts that stick up slightly to each side. His robust features often cast a shadow over his face, revealing only his striking blue pupils.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.77050961Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.77051181Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.77051478Z         "In his true form, after sustaining permanent damage from All For One, Toshinori's declining health reduced him to a very skinny man with sharp, angular features and long limbs, his neck extended, his eyebrows absent and the sclera of his eyes turned black. His hair is wavy, with two long strands coming down from his hairline and framing his face. He possesses a large scar covering most of the left side of his chest, having lost his stomach and some of his lungs' respiratory system. It is common for him to spout blood from his mouth when excited or surprised. He typically wears baggy clothing to accommodate the change in body mass between forms, but after Toshinori's tenure as a hero, he starts wearing clothes that fit him in his regular form, as he no longer needs big clothes that fit his muscle form.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.77051695Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.77051953Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.77052215Z         'Personally, I think this is a corny catchphrase. However, one must admit that the My Hero Academia franchise itself is geared towards a younger audience.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770524441Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770526571Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770528751Z         'Perhaps, this is genre appropriate.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770530961Z         '\n',
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770533061Z       owner: '019a612c-536e-7839-9fc5-6d342b574cdb',
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770548322Z       date_created: 2025-11-08T01:54:52.861Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770550692Z       last_modified: 2025-11-08T01:55:01.349Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770552822Z       folderId: '019a612e-ec92-7ddf-b0cc-92cbbeb4ec00'
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770554962Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770557132Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770559243Z       _id: '019a612d-8c2e-7926-9079-576d5d60af0a',
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770561412Z       title: 'Concept Design',
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770563533Z       content: '# Why Concept Design?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770565663Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770568433Z         'Concept design is a new approach to software development that attempts to find greater modularity in the structuring of the functionality of applications. The key idea is to break the functionality down into separable, modular services called *concepts*, each of which can be specified, implemented and understood separately -- by users and by developers. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770570633Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770572763Z         'The advantages of concept design include:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770575653Z         '- Improved separation of concerns resulting in simpler and more robust design and implementation;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770577873Z         '- Greater recognition of reusable behaviors, so reduced work for designers and developers and more familiar interactions for users;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770580534Z         '- Improved focus on the purposes and motivations of the functionality, since each concept is closely targeted at delivering a particular function of value in the context of the larger app.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770582694Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770584794Z         '## What is a concept?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770586954Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770600755Z         'A concept is a reusable unit of user-facing functionality that serves a well-defined and intelligible purpose. Each concept maintains its own state, and interacts with the user (and with other concepts) through atomic actions. Some actions are performed by users; others are output actions that occur spontaneously under the control of the concept.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770604575Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770608605Z         'A concept typically involves objects of several different kinds, holding relationships between them in its state. For example, the *Upvote* concept, whose purpose is to rank items by popularity, maintains a relationship between the items and the users who have approved or disapproved of them. The state of a concept must be sufficiently rich to support the concept‚Äôs behavior; if *Upvote* lacked information about users, for example, it would not be able to prevent double voting. But the concept state should be no richer than it need be: *Upvote* would *not* include anything about a user beyond the user‚Äôs identity, since the user‚Äôs name (for example) plays no role in the concept‚Äôs behavior.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770612185Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770615546Z         'A concept will generally be implemented as a backend service, with its state made persistent using a database. The behavior of the concept is thus captured by an API specification that is similar in many respects to that of conventional backend services. At the same time, because all concepts are user facing, the behavior of a concept is also generally a human behavioral protocol. For example, the *RestaurantReservation* concept whose actions are *reserve*, *cancel*, *seat*, etc., can be viewed by a developer as a backend API with functions/endpoints corresponding to the actions, and to a human user as the pattern of behavior that one engages in for restaurant reservations: reserving, perhaps canceling, being seated on arrival, etc.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770624526Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770628266Z         '## Compared to Concepts in Conceptual Modeling\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770632027Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770647357Z         'In contrast to the way the word is sometimes used in other settings, a concept is not an element in an ontology. In the field of conceptual modeling, a ‚Äúconceptual model‚Äù is often a data model in which the concepts are entities. Richer kinds of conceptual model have been defined that incorporate be- havior, for example, by defining the concepts as objects (or more accurately classes) with their own internal behavior. These approaches do not allow a modular treatment of concepts, however. The behavior associated with a concept typically involves multiple classes of objects, and modifications that involve their relationships to one another. For example, the behavior of the *Upvote* concept is to associate votes with both particular items and with the users who issued the votes (in order to prevent double voting).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770649717Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770652008Z         '## Concept Reuse and Familiarity\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770654148Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770656728Z         'Most concepts are reusable across applications; thus the same *Upvote* concept appears for upvoting comments in the New York Times and for upvoting answers on Stack Overflow. A concept can also be instantiated multiple times within the same application to play different roles.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770658898Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770661138Z         'This archetypal nature of concepts is essential. From the user‚Äôs perspective, it gives the familiarity that makes concepts easy to understand: a user encountering the same context in a new setting brings their understanding of that concept from their experience in previous settings.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770663318Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770674329Z         'From a designer‚Äôs perspective, it allows concepts to be repositories of design knowledge and experience. When a developer implements *Upvote*, even if they can‚Äôt reuse the code of a prior implementation, they can rely on all the discoveries and refinements previously made. Many of these are apparent in the behavior of the concept itself, but others are associated with the implementation, or are subtle enough to need explicit description. The community of designers could develop ‚Äúconcept catalogs‚Äù that capture all this knowledge, along with relationships between concepts (for example, that *Upvote* often relies on the *Session* concept for identifying users, which itself is associated with the *UserAuthentication* concept for authenticating users).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770678039Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770681609Z         '## Concept Independence\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770684959Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.77068825Z         'Perhaps the most significant distinguishing feature of concepts, in comparison to other modularity schemes, is their mutual independence. Each concept is defined without reference to any other concepts, and can be understood in isolation.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.77069158Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.77069561Z         'Early work on mental models established the principle that, in a robust model, the different elements must be independently understandable. The same holds in software: the reason a user can make sense of a new social media app, for example, is that each of the concepts (*Post*, *Comment*, *Upvote*, *Friend*, etc) are not only familiar but also separable, so that understanding one doesn‚Äôt require understanding another.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.7706995Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.77070353Z         'Concept independence lets design scale, because individual concepts can be worked on by different designers or design teams, and brought together later. Reuse requires independence too, because coupling between concepts would prevent a concept from being adopted without also including the concepts it depends on.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770731052Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770737852Z         'Polymorphism is key to independence: the designer of a concept should strive to make the concept as free as possible of any assumptions about the content and interpretation of objects passed as action arguments. Even if a *Comment* concept is used within an app only for comments on posts, it should be described as applying comments to arbitrary targets, defined only by their identity.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770740252Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770742473Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770744622Z         '## Separation of concerns\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770746743Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770748923Z         'One of the key advances of concept design is a more effective *separation of concerns* than is typical in software designs. This means that each concept addresses only a single, coherent aspect of the functionality of the application, and does not conflate aspects of functionality that could easily be separated. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770751063Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770753853Z         'In a traditional design, in contrast, concerns are often conflated, especially around objects (or classes). For example, it is common for a *User* class to handle all kinds of functions associated with users: authentication, profiles, naming, choice of communication channels for notification, and more. In a concept design, these would be separated into different concepts: one for authentication, one for profiles, one for naming, one for notification, and so on. The state declaration form makes it easy to associate the appropriate properties or fields with user objects in each concept. For example, the *UserAuthentication* concept may have a state that maps user identifiers to usernames and passwords; the *Profile* concept may map user identifiers to bios and thumbnail images; the *Notification* concept may map user identifiers to phone numbers and email addresses to be used as notification channels.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770756073Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770758243Z         '## Completeness of functionality\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770760363Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770782925Z         `Another key distinction between concept design and traditional design is that concepts are *complete* with respect to their functionality and don't rely on functionality from other concepts. For example, a *Notification* concept that has an action to notify a user cannot "make a call" to an action of an emailing or text messaging context to actually deliver a notification. Instead that functionality would be part of the *Notification* concept itself. It is always possible to separate out some functionality into another concept (and to sync the concepts together to achieve some combined functionality) so long as the concept that remains is still coherent and fulfills all of its functionality without dependencies.\n` +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770786915Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770790215Z         '## Composition by synchronization\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770793895Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770798176Z         "Because concepts are fully independent of one another, they cannot refer to each other or use each other's services. Concepts are therefore composed using *synchronizations* (or *syncs*). A sync is a rule that says that *when* an action happens in one concept, *where* the state of some concept has some property, *then* some action happens in another concept. For example, a sync may say that *when* a post p is deleted (in the *Post* concept, through the occurrence of an action), and *where* c is a comment on the post p (in the *Comment* concept), then comment c is deleted (in the *Comment* concept). This can be written\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770804786Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770807106Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770809276Z         'sync CascadePostDeletion\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770811506Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770813656Z         '\tPost.delete (p)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770815766Z         'where \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770817906Z         '\tin Comment: target of c is p\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770820137Z         'then \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770822257Z         '\tComment.delete (c)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770824357Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770826487Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770828627Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770830977Z         'Not that the syncs is not only causing an action to happen but also providing input arguments to actions (in this case the comment to be deleted).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770833147Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770835327Z         'A sync can have multiple actions in its when and then clauses, and can refer to the state of multiple concepts in the where clause. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770837488Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770839578Z         'Some other examples of how syncs are used:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770842218Z         "- When a user comments on another user's post, the second user is notified\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770844388Z         '- When a user exhibits some good behavior, karma is awarded to them\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770846518Z         '- When a user checks out a shopping cart, their credit card is charged.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770848648Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770850838Z         'Syncs can be used for authentication and authorization. In these case, it is common to represent requests made by a user as actions of a kind of pseudo concept (which is usually called *Request*). For example, a sync might say that if a user requests to delete a post, and the user is the author of the post, then the deletion can go ahead:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770853019Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770855199Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770857329Z         'sync DeletePost\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770859499Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:45.770861619Z         '\tRequest.delet'... 112 more characters,

2025-11-08T01:57:46.084048178Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084050638Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084053438Z         `His catchphrase is: "Don't Fear, I am Here"\n` +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084055699Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084058379Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084061579Z         'In his empowered form, All Might is a towering figure with a powerfully muscular and well-defined physique, resembling a classic Western comic book superhero. He has chiseled facial features, including a strong jawline, pronounced cheekbones, and bushy eyebrows. His short blond hair is swept backward, with two distinct tufts that stick up slightly to each side. His robust features often cast a shadow over his face, revealing only his striking blue pupils.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084063769Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084065969Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084069689Z         "In his true form, after sustaining permanent damage from All For One, Toshinori's declining health reduced him to a very skinny man with sharp, angular features and long limbs, his neck extended, his eyebrows absent and the sclera of his eyes turned black. His hair is wavy, with two long strands coming down from his hairline and framing his face. He possesses a large scar covering most of the left side of his chest, having lost his stomach and some of his lungs' respiratory system. It is common for him to spout blood from his mouth when excited or surprised. He typically wears baggy clothing to accommodate the change in body mass between forms, but after Toshinori's tenure as a hero, he starts wearing clothes that fit him in his regular form, as he no longer needs big clothes that fit his muscle form.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.08408647Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.08408903Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.08409197Z         'Personally, I think this is a corny catchphrase. However, one must admit that the My Hero Academia franchise itself is geared towards a younger audience.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084094541Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084096861Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084099141Z         'Perhaps, this is genre appropriate.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084101561Z         '\n',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084103741Z       owner: '019a612c-536e-7839-9fc5-6d342b574cdb',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084106951Z       date_created: 2025-11-08T01:54:52.861Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084109402Z       last_modified: 2025-11-08T01:55:01.349Z
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084111802Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084114092Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084116522Z       _id: '019a612d-8c2e-7926-9079-576d5d60af0a',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084118932Z       title: 'Concept Design',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084121332Z       content: '# Why Concept Design?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084123602Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084132093Z         'Concept design is a new approach to software development that attempts to find greater modularity in the structuring of the functionality of applications. The key idea is to break the functionality down into separable, modular services called *concepts*, each of which can be specified, implemented and understood separately -- by users and by developers. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084134593Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084136993Z         'The advantages of concept design include:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084139923Z         '- Improved separation of concerns resulting in simpler and more robust design and implementation;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084142483Z         '- Greater recognition of reusable behaviors, so reduced work for designers and developers and more familiar interactions for users;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084145284Z         '- Improved focus on the purposes and motivations of the functionality, since each concept is closely targeted at delivering a particular function of value in the context of the larger app.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084147633Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084149894Z         '## What is a concept?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084152194Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084163094Z         'A concept is a reusable unit of user-facing functionality that serves a well-defined and intelligible purpose. Each concept maintains its own state, and interacts with the user (and with other concepts) through atomic actions. Some actions are performed by users; others are output actions that occur spontaneously under the control of the concept.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084165874Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084169385Z         'A concept typically involves objects of several different kinds, holding relationships between them in its state. For example, the *Upvote* concept, whose purpose is to rank items by popularity, maintains a relationship between the items and the users who have approved or disapproved of them. The state of a concept must be sufficiently rich to support the concept‚Äôs behavior; if *Upvote* lacked information about users, for example, it would not be able to prevent double voting. But the concept state should be no richer than it need be: *Upvote* would *not* include anything about a user beyond the user‚Äôs identity, since the user‚Äôs name (for example) plays no role in the concept‚Äôs behavior.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084171815Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084174035Z         'A concept will generally be implemented as a backend service, with its state made persistent using a database. The behavior of the concept is thus captured by an API specification that is similar in many respects to that of conventional backend services. At the same time, because all concepts are user facing, the behavior of a concept is also generally a human behavioral protocol. For example, the *RestaurantReservation* concept whose actions are *reserve*, *cancel*, *seat*, etc., can be viewed by a developer as a backend API with functions/endpoints corresponding to the actions, and to a human user as the pattern of behavior that one engages in for restaurant reservations: reserving, perhaps canceling, being seated on arrival, etc.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084181475Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084184015Z         '## Compared to Concepts in Conceptual Modeling\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084186236Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084188706Z         'In contrast to the way the word is sometimes used in other settings, a concept is not an element in an ontology. In the field of conceptual modeling, a ‚Äúconceptual model‚Äù is often a data model in which the concepts are entities. Richer kinds of conceptual model have been defined that incorporate be- havior, for example, by defining the concepts as objects (or more accurately classes) with their own internal behavior. These approaches do not allow a modular treatment of concepts, however. The behavior associated with a concept typically involves multiple classes of objects, and modifications that involve their relationships to one another. For example, the behavior of the *Upvote* concept is to associate votes with both particular items and with the users who issued the votes (in order to prevent double voting).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084191146Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084193346Z         '## Concept Reuse and Familiarity\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084195616Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084198296Z         'Most concepts are reusable across applications; thus the same *Upvote* concept appears for upvoting comments in the New York Times and for upvoting answers on Stack Overflow. A concept can also be instantiated multiple times within the same application to play different roles.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084200667Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084203027Z         'This archetypal nature of concepts is essential. From the user‚Äôs perspective, it gives the familiarity that makes concepts easy to understand: a user encountering the same context in a new setting brings their understanding of that concept from their experience in previous settings.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084205317Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084213887Z         'From a designer‚Äôs perspective, it allows concepts to be repositories of design knowledge and experience. When a developer implements *Upvote*, even if they can‚Äôt reuse the code of a prior implementation, they can rely on all the discoveries and refinements previously made. Many of these are apparent in the behavior of the concept itself, but others are associated with the implementation, or are subtle enough to need explicit description. The community of designers could develop ‚Äúconcept catalogs‚Äù that capture all this knowledge, along with relationships between concepts (for example, that *Upvote* often relies on the *Session* concept for identifying users, which itself is associated with the *UserAuthentication* concept for authenticating users).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084216607Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084219168Z         '## Concept Independence\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084221428Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084223968Z         'Perhaps the most significant distinguishing feature of concepts, in comparison to other modularity schemes, is their mutual independence. Each concept is defined without reference to any other concepts, and can be understood in isolation.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084226288Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084233228Z         'Early work on mental models established the principle that, in a robust model, the different elements must be independently understandable. The same holds in software: the reason a user can make sense of a new social media app, for example, is that each of the concepts (*Post*, *Comment*, *Upvote*, *Friend*, etc) are not only familiar but also separable, so that understanding one doesn‚Äôt require understanding another.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084235878Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084238218Z         'Concept independence lets design scale, because individual concepts can be worked on by different designers or design teams, and brought together later. Reuse requires independence too, because coupling between concepts would prevent a concept from being adopted without also including the concepts it depends on.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084240439Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084243179Z         'Polymorphism is key to independence: the designer of a concept should strive to make the concept as free as possible of any assumptions about the content and interpretation of objects passed as action arguments. Even if a *Comment* concept is used within an app only for comments on posts, it should be described as applying comments to arbitrary targets, defined only by their identity.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084245539Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084247799Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084249869Z         '## Separation of concerns\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084252009Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084254179Z         'One of the key advances of concept design is a more effective *separation of concerns* than is typical in software designs. This means that each concept addresses only a single, coherent aspect of the functionality of the application, and does not conflate aspects of functionality that could easily be separated. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084256459Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.08427063Z         'In a traditional design, in contrast, concerns are often conflated, especially around objects (or classes). For example, it is common for a *User* class to handle all kinds of functions associated with users: authentication, profiles, naming, choice of communication channels for notification, and more. In a concept design, these would be separated into different concepts: one for authentication, one for profiles, one for naming, one for notification, and so on. The state declaration form makes it easy to associate the appropriate properties or fields with user objects in each concept. For example, the *UserAuthentication* concept may have a state that maps user identifiers to usernames and passwords; the *Profile* concept may map user identifiers to bios and thumbnail images; the *Notification* concept may map user identifiers to phone numbers and email addresses to be used as notification channels.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084273191Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.0842754Z         '## Completeness of functionality\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084277461Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084292421Z         `Another key distinction between concept design and traditional design is that concepts are *complete* with respect to their functionality and don't rely on functionality from other concepts. For example, a *Notification* concept that has an action to notify a user cannot "make a call" to an action of an emailing or text messaging context to actually deliver a notification. Instead that functionality would be part of the *Notification* concept itself. It is always possible to separate out some functionality into another concept (and to sync the concepts together to achieve some combined functionality) so long as the concept that remains is still coherent and fulfills all of its functionality without dependencies.\n` +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084295082Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084301972Z         '## Composition by synchronization\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084304682Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084309893Z         "Because concepts are fully independent of one another, they cannot refer to each other or use each other's services. Concepts are therefore composed using *synchronizations* (or *syncs*). A sync is a rule that says that *when* an action happens in one concept, *where* the state of some concept has some property, *then* some action happens in another concept. For example, a sync may say that *when* a post p is deleted (in the *Post* concept, through the occurrence of an action), and *where* c is a comment on the post p (in the *Comment* concept), then comment c is deleted (in the *Comment* concept). This can be written\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084312233Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084314653Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084317163Z         'sync CascadePostDeletion\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084319663Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084322113Z         '\tPost.delete (p)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084324393Z         'where \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084326853Z         '\tin Comment: target of c is p\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084329143Z         'then \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084331464Z         '\tComment.delete (c)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084333724Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084336154Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084338434Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084340734Z         'Not that the syncs is not only causing an action to happen but also providing input arguments to actions (in this case the comment to be deleted).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084343104Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084345534Z         'A sync can have multiple actions in its when and then clauses, and can refer to the state of multiple concepts in the where clause. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084347764Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084350125Z         'Some other examples of how syncs are used:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084353045Z         "- When a user comments on another user's post, the second user is notified\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084355625Z         '- When a user exhibits some good behavior, karma is awarded to them\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084358075Z         '- When a user checks out a shopping cart, their credit card is charged.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084360495Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084363175Z         'Syncs can be used for authentication and authorization. In these case, it is common to represent requests made by a user as actions of a kind of pseudo concept (which is usually called *Request*). For example, a sync might say that if a user requests to delete a post, and the user is the author of the post, then the deletion can go ahead:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084365556Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084367865Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084370126Z         'sync DeletePost\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084372496Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084374916Z         '\tRequest.delet'... 112 more characters,
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084377216Z       owner: '019a612c-536e-7839-9fc5-6d342b574cdb',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084379666Z       date_created: 2025-11-08T01:56:06.318Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084381996Z       last_modified: 2025-11-08T01:56:11.590Z
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084384377Z     }
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084386857Z   ]
2025-11-08T01:57:46.084389417Z }

2025-11-08T01:57:46.358520104Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358522344Z       _id: '019a612c-6d3d-7231-b863-6547eb8444ae',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358525344Z       title: "Don't Fear",
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358528284Z       content: "<b>Toshinori Yagi</b> (ÂÖ´„ÇÑÊú®„Åé‰øä„Å®„ÅóÂÖ∏„ÅÆ„Çä Yagi Toshinori?), also known as All Might, is one of the main characters of My Hero Academia. He is the former No. 1 Pro Hero who bore the title of the world's Symbol of Peace.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358533124Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358535425Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358538505Z         "All Might was the eighth holder of the One For All Quirk after receiving it from Nana Shimura. He has since passed the torch onto Izuku Midoriya, whom he trained to be his successor. After using up all the embers of One For All to defeat All For One, All Might retired and ended his era as the world's greatest hero.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358551295Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358553646Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358556956Z         "He taught Foundational Hero Studies at U.A. High School, and now serves as the school's vice principal eight years after the Final War.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358559176Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358561316Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358563446Z         `His catchphrase is: "Don't Fear, I am Here"\n` +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358565616Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358567696Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358570776Z         'In his empowered form, All Might is a towering figure with a powerfully muscular and well-defined physique, resembling a classic Western comic book superhero. He has chiseled facial features, including a strong jawline, pronounced cheekbones, and bushy eyebrows. His short blond hair is swept backward, with two distinct tufts that stick up slightly to each side. His robust features often cast a shadow over his face, revealing only his striking blue pupils.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358573027Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358575107Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358578137Z         "In his true form, after sustaining permanent damage from All For One, Toshinori's declining health reduced him to a very skinny man with sharp, angular features and long limbs, his neck extended, his eyebrows absent and the sclera of his eyes turned black. His hair is wavy, with two long strands coming down from his hairline and framing his face. He possesses a large scar covering most of the left side of his chest, having lost his stomach and some of his lungs' respiratory system. It is common for him to spout blood from his mouth when excited or surprised. He typically wears baggy clothing to accommodate the change in body mass between forms, but after Toshinori's tenure as a hero, he starts wearing clothes that fit him in his regular form, as he no longer needs big clothes that fit his muscle form.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358580417Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358582517Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358585257Z         'Personally, I think this is a corny catchphrase. However, one must admit that the My Hero Academia franchise itself is geared towards a younger audience.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358587407Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358589528Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358591677Z         'Perhaps, this is genre appropriate.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358593828Z         '\n',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358596008Z       owner: '019a612c-536e-7839-9fc5-6d342b574cdb',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358598728Z       date_created: 2025-11-08T01:54:52.861Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358600848Z       last_modified: 2025-11-08T01:55:01.349Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358603018Z       folderId: '019a612e-ec92-7ddf-b0cc-92cbbeb4ec00'
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358605148Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358607318Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358609449Z       _id: '019a612d-8c2e-7926-9079-576d5d60af0a',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358611589Z       title: 'Concept Design',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358613769Z       content: '# Why Concept Design?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358615889Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358618629Z         'Concept design is a new approach to software development that attempts to find greater modularity in the structuring of the functionality of applications. The key idea is to break the functionality down into separable, modular services called *concepts*, each of which can be specified, implemented and understood separately -- by users and by developers. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358627899Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.35863156Z         'The advantages of concept design include:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.35863593Z         '- Improved separation of concerns resulting in simpler and more robust design and implementation;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.35863988Z         '- Greater recognition of reusable behaviors, so reduced work for designers and developers and more familiar interactions for users;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.35864412Z         '- Improved focus on the purposes and motivations of the functionality, since each concept is closely targeted at delivering a particular function of value in the context of the larger app.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358647801Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358651281Z         '## What is a concept?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358654771Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358670452Z         'A concept is a reusable unit of user-facing functionality that serves a well-defined and intelligible purpose. Each concept maintains its own state, and interacts with the user (and with other concepts) through atomic actions. Some actions are performed by users; others are output actions that occur spontaneously under the control of the concept.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358674592Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358678422Z         'A concept typically involves objects of several different kinds, holding relationships between them in its state. For example, the *Upvote* concept, whose purpose is to rank items by popularity, maintains a relationship between the items and the users who have approved or disapproved of them. The state of a concept must be sufficiently rich to support the concept‚Äôs behavior; if *Upvote* lacked information about users, for example, it would not be able to prevent double voting. But the concept state should be no richer than it need be: *Upvote* would *not* include anything about a user beyond the user‚Äôs identity, since the user‚Äôs name (for example) plays no role in the concept‚Äôs behavior.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358680682Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358682933Z         'A concept will generally be implemented as a backend service, with its state made persistent using a database. The behavior of the concept is thus captured by an API specification that is similar in many respects to that of conventional backend services. At the same time, because all concepts are user facing, the behavior of a concept is also generally a human behavioral protocol. For example, the *RestaurantReservation* concept whose actions are *reserve*, *cancel*, *seat*, etc., can be viewed by a developer as a backend API with functions/endpoints corresponding to the actions, and to a human user as the pattern of behavior that one engages in for restaurant reservations: reserving, perhaps canceling, being seated on arrival, etc.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358685133Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358689853Z         '## Compared to Concepts in Conceptual Modeling\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358692073Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358694413Z         'In contrast to the way the word is sometimes used in other settings, a concept is not an element in an ontology. In the field of conceptual modeling, a ‚Äúconceptual model‚Äù is often a data model in which the concepts are entities. Richer kinds of conceptual model have been defined that incorporate be- havior, for example, by defining the concepts as objects (or more accurately classes) with their own internal behavior. These approaches do not allow a modular treatment of concepts, however. The behavior associated with a concept typically involves multiple classes of objects, and modifications that involve their relationships to one another. For example, the behavior of the *Upvote* concept is to associate votes with both particular items and with the users who issued the votes (in order to prevent double voting).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358701234Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358703474Z         '## Concept Reuse and Familiarity\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358705654Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358738326Z         'Most concepts are reusable across applications; thus the same *Upvote* concept appears for upvoting comments in the New York Times and for upvoting answers on Stack Overflow. A concept can also be instantiated multiple times within the same application to play different roles.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358744436Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358746776Z         'This archetypal nature of concepts is essential. From the user‚Äôs perspective, it gives the familiarity that makes concepts easy to understand: a user encountering the same context in a new setting brings their understanding of that concept from their experience in previous settings.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358748966Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358764167Z         'From a designer‚Äôs perspective, it allows concepts to be repositories of design knowledge and experience. When a developer implements *Upvote*, even if they can‚Äôt reuse the code of a prior implementation, they can rely on all the discoveries and refinements previously made. Many of these are apparent in the behavior of the concept itself, but others are associated with the implementation, or are subtle enough to need explicit description. The community of designers could develop ‚Äúconcept catalogs‚Äù that capture all this knowledge, along with relationships between concepts (for example, that *Upvote* often relies on the *Session* concept for identifying users, which itself is associated with the *UserAuthentication* concept for authenticating users).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358766747Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358768887Z         '## Concept Independence\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358771387Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358773727Z         'Perhaps the most significant distinguishing feature of concepts, in comparison to other modularity schemes, is their mutual independence. Each concept is defined without reference to any other concepts, and can be understood in isolation.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358775888Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358778538Z         'Early work on mental models established the principle that, in a robust model, the different elements must be independently understandable. The same holds in software: the reason a user can make sense of a new social media app, for example, is that each of the concepts (*Post*, *Comment*, *Upvote*, *Friend*, etc) are not only familiar but also separable, so that understanding one doesn‚Äôt require understanding another.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358780718Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358783108Z         'Concept independence lets design scale, because individual concepts can be worked on by different designers or design teams, and brought together later. Reuse requires independence too, because coupling between concepts would prevent a concept from being adopted without also including the concepts it depends on.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358785248Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358788058Z         'Polymorphism is key to independence: the designer of a concept should strive to make the concept as free as possible of any assumptions about the content and interpretation of objects passed as action arguments. Even if a *Comment* concept is used within an app only for comments on posts, it should be described as applying comments to arbitrary targets, defined only by their identity.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358790248Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358792328Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358794419Z         '## Separation of concerns\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358796559Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358798659Z         'One of the key advances of concept design is a more effective *separation of concerns* than is typical in software designs. This means that each concept addresses only a single, coherent aspect of the functionality of the application, and does not conflate aspects of functionality that could easily be separated. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358805329Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358809829Z         'In a traditional design, in contrast, concerns are often conflated, especially around objects (or classes). For example, it is common for a *User* class to handle all kinds of functions associated with users: authentication, profiles, naming, choice of communication channels for notification, and more. In a concept design, these would be separated into different concepts: one for authentication, one for profiles, one for naming, one for notification, and so on. The state declaration form makes it easy to associate the appropriate properties or fields with user objects in each concept. For example, the *UserAuthentication* concept may have a state that maps user identifiers to usernames and passwords; the *Profile* concept may map user identifiers to bios and thumbnail images; the *Notification* concept may map user identifiers to phone numbers and email addresses to be used as notification channels.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.35881223Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.35881457Z         '## Completeness of functionality\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.35881672Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358830161Z         `Another key distinction between concept design and traditional design is that concepts are *complete* with respect to their functionality and don't rely on functionality from other concepts. For example, a *Notification* concept that has an action to notify a user cannot "make a call" to an action of an emailing or text messaging context to actually deliver a notification. Instead that functionality would be part of the *Notification* concept itself. It is always possible to separate out some functionality into another concept (and to sync the concepts together to achieve some combined functionality) so long as the concept that remains is still coherent and fulfills all of its functionality without dependencies.\n` +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358832581Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358834751Z         '## Composition by synchronization\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358836941Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358839721Z         "Because concepts are fully independent of one another, they cannot refer to each other or use each other's services. Concepts are therefore composed using *synchronizations* (or *syncs*). A sync is a rule that says that *when* an action happens in one concept, *where* the state of some concept has some property, *then* some action happens in another concept. For example, a sync may say that *when* a post p is deleted (in the *Post* concept, through the occurrence of an action), and *where* c is a comment on the post p (in the *Comment* concept), then comment c is deleted (in the *Comment* concept). This can be written\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358841951Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358844071Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358846651Z         'sync CascadePostDeletion\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358848842Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358850992Z         '\tPost.delete (p)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358853062Z         'where \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358855232Z         '\tin Comment: target of c is p\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358857362Z         'then \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358859522Z         '\tComment.delete (c)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358861682Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358863783Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358865912Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358868103Z         'Not that the syncs is not only causing an action to happen but also providing input arguments to actions (in this case the comment to be deleted).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358873833Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358878033Z         'A sync can have multiple actions in its when and then clauses, and can refer to the state of multiple concepts in the where clause. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358880223Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358882444Z         'Some other examples of how syncs are used:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358885194Z         "- When a user comments on another user's post, the second user is notified\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358887384Z         '- When a user exhibits some good behavior, karma is awarded to them\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358889614Z         '- When a user checks out a shopping cart, their credit card is charged.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358891734Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358893984Z         'Syncs can be used for authentication and authorization. In these case, it is common to represent requests made by a user as actions of a kind of pseudo concept (which is usually called *Request*). For example, a sync might say that if a user requests to delete a post, and the user is the author of the post, then the deletion can go ahead:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358896094Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358898214Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358900414Z         'sync DeletePost\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358902585Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.358904755Z         '\tRequest.delet'... 112 more characters,

2025-11-08T01:57:46.676893136Z       content: "<b>Toshinori Yagi</b> (ÂÖ´„ÇÑÊú®„Åé‰øä„Å®„ÅóÂÖ∏„ÅÆ„Çä Yagi Toshinori?), also known as All Might, is one of the main characters of My Hero Academia. He is the former No. 1 Pro Hero who bore the title of the world's Symbol of Peace.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676895336Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676897976Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676900896Z         "All Might was the eighth holder of the One For All Quirk after receiving it from Nana Shimura. He has since passed the torch onto Izuku Midoriya, whom he trained to be his successor. After using up all the embers of One For All to defeat All For One, All Might retired and ended his era as the world's greatest hero.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676903227Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676905417Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676908087Z         "He taught Foundational Hero Studies at U.A. High School, and now serves as the school's vice principal eight years after the Final War.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676910237Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676912477Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676914657Z         `His catchphrase is: "Don't Fear, I am Here"\n` +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676916847Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676918937Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676921677Z         'In his empowered form, All Might is a towering figure with a powerfully muscular and well-defined physique, resembling a classic Western comic book superhero. He has chiseled facial features, including a strong jawline, pronounced cheekbones, and bushy eyebrows. His short blond hair is swept backward, with two distinct tufts that stick up slightly to each side. His robust features often cast a shadow over his face, revealing only his striking blue pupils.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676923868Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676925938Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676932958Z         "In his true form, after sustaining permanent damage from All For One, Toshinori's declining health reduced him to a very skinny man with sharp, angular features and long limbs, his neck extended, his eyebrows absent and the sclera of his eyes turned black. His hair is wavy, with two long strands coming down from his hairline and framing his face. He possesses a large scar covering most of the left side of his chest, having lost his stomach and some of his lungs' respiratory system. It is common for him to spout blood from his mouth when excited or surprised. He typically wears baggy clothing to accommodate the change in body mass between forms, but after Toshinori's tenure as a hero, he starts wearing clothes that fit him in his regular form, as he no longer needs big clothes that fit his muscle form.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676935758Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676937869Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676940619Z         'Personally, I think this is a corny catchphrase. However, one must admit that the My Hero Academia franchise itself is geared towards a younger audience.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676942769Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676944859Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676947049Z         'Perhaps, this is genre appropriate.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676949179Z         '\n',

2025-11-08T01:57:46.67695846Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:46.67696066Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:46.6769672Z       _id: '019a612d-8c2e-7926-9079-576d5d60af0a',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.67696962Z       title: 'Concept Design',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.6769718Z       content: '# Why Concept Design?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.67697392Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676976661Z         'Concept design is a new approach to software development that attempts to find greater modularity in the structuring of the functionality of applications. The key idea is to break the functionality down into separable, modular services called *concepts*, each of which can be specified, implemented and understood separately -- by users and by developers. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676978871Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676981061Z         'The advantages of concept design include:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676983711Z         '- Improved separation of concerns resulting in simpler and more robust design and implementation;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676985841Z         '- Greater recognition of reusable behaviors, so reduced work for designers and developers and more familiar interactions for users;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676988801Z         '- Improved focus on the purposes and motivations of the functionality, since each concept is closely targeted at delivering a particular function of value in the context of the larger app.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676990941Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676993101Z         '## What is a concept?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.676995242Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677014093Z         'A concept is a reusable unit of user-facing functionality that serves a well-defined and intelligible purpose. Each concept maintains its own state, and interacts with the user (and with other concepts) through atomic actions. Some actions are performed by users; others are output actions that occur spontaneously under the control of the concept.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677016753Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677019553Z         'A concept typically involves objects of several different kinds, holding relationships between them in its state. For example, the *Upvote* concept, whose purpose is to rank items by popularity, maintains a relationship between the items and the users who have approved or disapproved of them. The state of a concept must be sufficiently rich to support the concept‚Äôs behavior; if *Upvote* lacked information about users, for example, it would not be able to prevent double voting. But the concept state should be no richer than it need be: *Upvote* would *not* include anything about a user beyond the user‚Äôs identity, since the user‚Äôs name (for example) plays no role in the concept‚Äôs behavior.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677021713Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677025563Z         'A concept will generally be implemented as a backend service, with its state made persistent using a database. The behavior of the concept is thus captured by an API specification that is similar in many respects to that of conventional backend services. At the same time, because all concepts are user facing, the behavior of a concept is also generally a human behavioral protocol. For example, the *RestaurantReservation* concept whose actions are *reserve*, *cancel*, *seat*, etc., can be viewed by a developer as a backend API with functions/endpoints corresponding to the actions, and to a human user as the pattern of behavior that one engages in for restaurant reservations: reserving, perhaps canceling, being seated on arrival, etc.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677028594Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677032484Z         '## Compared to Concepts in Conceptual Modeling\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677036354Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677040404Z         'In contrast to the way the word is sometimes used in other settings, a concept is not an element in an ontology. In the field of conceptual modeling, a ‚Äúconceptual model‚Äù is often a data model in which the concepts are entities. Richer kinds of conceptual model have been defined that incorporate be- havior, for example, by defining the concepts as objects (or more accurately classes) with their own internal behavior. These approaches do not allow a modular treatment of concepts, however. The behavior associated with a concept typically involves multiple classes of objects, and modifications that involve their relationships to one another. For example, the behavior of the *Upvote* concept is to associate votes with both particular items and with the users who issued the votes (in order to prevent double voting).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677049675Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677053205Z         '## Concept Reuse and Familiarity\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677056465Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677060505Z         'Most concepts are reusable across applications; thus the same *Upvote* concept appears for upvoting comments in the New York Times and for upvoting answers on Stack Overflow. A concept can also be instantiated multiple times within the same application to play different roles.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677063665Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677066676Z         'This archetypal nature of concepts is essential. From the user‚Äôs perspective, it gives the familiarity that makes concepts easy to understand: a user encountering the same context in a new setting brings their understanding of that concept from their experience in previous settings.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677069696Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677082016Z         'From a designer‚Äôs perspective, it allows concepts to be repositories of design knowledge and experience. When a developer implements *Upvote*, even if they can‚Äôt reuse the code of a prior implementation, they can rely on all the discoveries and refinements previously made. Many of these are apparent in the behavior of the concept itself, but others are associated with the implementation, or are subtle enough to need explicit description. The community of designers could develop ‚Äúconcept catalogs‚Äù that capture all this knowledge, along with relationships between concepts (for example, that *Upvote* often relies on the *Session* concept for identifying users, which itself is associated with the *UserAuthentication* concept for authenticating users).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677086117Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677089937Z         '## Concept Independence\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677092577Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677094777Z         'Perhaps the most significant distinguishing feature of concepts, in comparison to other modularity schemes, is their mutual independence. Each concept is defined without reference to any other concepts, and can be understood in isolation.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677096907Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677099617Z         'Early work on mental models established the principle that, in a robust model, the different elements must be independently understandable. The same holds in software: the reason a user can make sense of a new social media app, for example, is that each of the concepts (*Post*, *Comment*, *Upvote*, *Friend*, etc) are not only familiar but also separable, so that understanding one doesn‚Äôt require understanding another.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677101847Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677104018Z         'Concept independence lets design scale, because individual concepts can be worked on by different designers or design teams, and brought together later. Reuse requires independence too, because coupling between concepts would prevent a concept from being adopted without also including the concepts it depends on.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677106148Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677108928Z         'Polymorphism is key to independence: the designer of a concept should strive to make the concept as free as possible of any assumptions about the content and interpretation of objects passed as action arguments. Even if a *Comment* concept is used within an app only for comments on posts, it should be described as applying comments to arbitrary targets, defined only by their identity.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677116458Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677118618Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677120728Z         '## Separation of concerns\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677122828Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677125229Z         'One of the key advances of concept design is a more effective *separation of concerns* than is typical in software designs. This means that each concept addresses only a single, coherent aspect of the functionality of the application, and does not conflate aspects of functionality that could easily be separated. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677127389Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677130289Z         'In a traditional design, in contrast, concerns are often conflated, especially around objects (or classes). For example, it is common for a *User* class to handle all kinds of functions associated with users: authentication, profiles, naming, choice of communication channels for notification, and more. In a concept design, these would be separated into different concepts: one for authentication, one for profiles, one for naming, one for notification, and so on. The state declaration form makes it easy to associate the appropriate properties or fields with user objects in each concept. For example, the *UserAuthentication* concept may have a state that maps user identifiers to usernames and passwords; the *Profile* concept may map user identifiers to bios and thumbnail images; the *Notification* concept may map user identifiers to phone numbers and email addresses to be used as notification channels.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677132449Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677134559Z         '## Completeness of functionality\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677136679Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.67714961Z         `Another key distinction between concept design and traditional design is that concepts are *complete* with respect to their functionality and don't rely on functionality from other concepts. For example, a *Notification* concept that has an action to notify a user cannot "make a call" to an action of an emailing or text messaging context to actually deliver a notification. Instead that functionality would be part of the *Notification* concept itself. It is always possible to separate out some functionality into another concept (and to sync the concepts together to achieve some combined functionality) so long as the concept that remains is still coherent and fulfills all of its functionality without dependencies.\n` +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.67715197Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.67715418Z         '## Composition by synchronization\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677156321Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677165811Z         "Because concepts are fully independent of one another, they cannot refer to each other or use each other's services. Concepts are therefore composed using *synchronizations* (or *syncs*). A sync is a rule that says that *when* an action happens in one concept, *where* the state of some concept has some property, *then* some action happens in another concept. For example, a sync may say that *when* a post p is deleted (in the *Post* concept, through the occurrence of an action), and *where* c is a comment on the post p (in the *Comment* concept), then comment c is deleted (in the *Comment* concept). This can be written\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677168181Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677170311Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677172541Z         'sync CascadePostDeletion\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677174742Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677176991Z         '\tPost.delete (p)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677182702Z         'where \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677184962Z         '\tin Comment: target of c is p\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677187102Z         'then \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677189222Z         '\tComment.delete (c)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677191412Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677193492Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677195632Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677197863Z         'Not that the syncs is not only causing an action to happen but also providing input arguments to actions (in this case the comment to be deleted).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677199983Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677202113Z         'A sync can have multiple actions in its when and then clauses, and can refer to the state of multiple concepts in the where clause. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677204263Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677206373Z         'Some other examples of how syncs are used:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677208983Z         "- When a user comments on another user's post, the second user is notified\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677211293Z         '- When a user exhibits some good behavior, karma is awarded to them\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677213473Z         '- When a user checks out a shopping cart, their credit card is charged.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677215564Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677217854Z         'Syncs can be used for authentication and authorization. In these case, it is common to represent requests made by a user as actions of a kind of pseudo concept (which is usually called *Request*). For example, a sync might say that if a user requests to delete a post, and the user is the author of the post, then the deletion can go ahead:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677220014Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677222114Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677224224Z         'sync DeletePost\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677226374Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677228544Z         '\tRequest.delet'... 112 more characters,
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677230734Z       owner: '019a612c-536e-7839-9fc5-6d342b574cdb',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677233025Z       date_created: 2025-11-08T01:56:06.318Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677235155Z       last_modified: 2025-11-08T01:56:11.590Z
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677237295Z     }
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677239445Z   ]
2025-11-08T01:57:46.677241625Z }
