2025-11-08T01:57:46.949945744Z Requesting.respond {
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949950274Z   request: '019a612f-1364-7954-8a23-6c77f9ec2338',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949953435Z   notes: [
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949956715Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949960235Z       _id: '019a612c-6d3d-7231-b863-6547eb8444ae',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949964225Z       title: "Don't Fear",
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949968305Z       content: "<b>Toshinori Yagi</b> (ÂÖ´„ÇÑÊú®„Åé‰øä„Å®„ÅóÂÖ∏„ÅÆ„Çä Yagi Toshinori?), also known as All Might, is one of the main characters of My Hero Academia. He is the former No. 1 Pro Hero who bore the title of the world's Symbol of Peace.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949971616Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949974456Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949978056Z         "All Might was the eighth holder of the One For All Quirk after receiving it from Nana Shimura. He has since passed the torch onto Izuku Midoriya, whom he trained to be his successor. After using up all the embers of One For All to defeat All For One, All Might retired and ended his era as the world's greatest hero.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949981166Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949984176Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949988156Z         "He taught Foundational Hero Studies at U.A. High School, and now serves as the school's vice principal eight years after the Final War.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949991066Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949994187Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.949997237Z         `His catchphrase is: "Don't Fear, I am Here"\n` +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950000187Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950003177Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950006937Z         'In his empowered form, All Might is a towering figure with a powerfully muscular and well-defined physique, resembling a classic Western comic book superhero. He has chiseled facial features, including a strong jawline, pronounced cheekbones, and bushy eyebrows. His short blond hair is swept backward, with two distinct tufts that stick up slightly to each side. His robust features often cast a shadow over his face, revealing only his striking blue pupils.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950040249Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950043949Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950048Z         "In his true form, after sustaining permanent damage from All For One, Toshinori's declining health reduced him to a very skinny man with sharp, angular features and long limbs, his neck extended, his eyebrows absent and the sclera of his eyes turned black. His hair is wavy, with two long strands coming down from his hairline and framing his face. He possesses a large scar covering most of the left side of his chest, having lost his stomach and some of his lungs' respiratory system. It is common for him to spout blood from his mouth when excited or surprised. He typically wears baggy clothing to accommodate the change in body mass between forms, but after Toshinori's tenure as a hero, he starts wearing clothes that fit him in his regular form, as he no longer needs big clothes that fit his muscle form.\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.95005105Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.95005391Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.95005774Z         'Personally, I think this is a corny catchphrase. However, one must admit that the My Hero Academia franchise itself is geared towards a younger audience.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.95006082Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950063721Z         '<br></br>\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950066811Z         'Perhaps, this is genre appropriate.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950069741Z         '\n',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950072621Z       owner: '019a612c-536e-7839-9fc5-6d342b574cdb',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950076181Z       date_created: 2025-11-08T01:54:52.861Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950079061Z       last_modified: 2025-11-08T01:55:01.349Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950082091Z       folderId: '019a612e-ec92-7ddf-b0cc-92cbbeb4ec00'
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950084922Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950087952Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950090882Z       _id: '019a612d-8c2e-7926-9079-576d5d60af0a',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950093842Z       title: 'Concept Design',
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950096722Z       content: '# Why Concept Design?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950099463Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950102903Z         'Concept design is a new approach to software development that attempts to find greater modularity in the structuring of the functionality of applications. The key idea is to break the functionality down into separable, modular services called *concepts*, each of which can be specified, implemented and understood separately -- by users and by developers. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950105883Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950109033Z         'The advantages of concept design include:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950112663Z         '- Improved separation of concerns resulting in simpler and more robust design and implementation;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950115713Z         '- Greater recognition of reusable behaviors, so reduced work for designers and developers and more familiar interactions for users;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950119904Z         '- Improved focus on the purposes and motivations of the functionality, since each concept is closely targeted at delivering a particular function of value in the context of the larger app.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950122744Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950125594Z         '## What is a concept?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950128824Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950143625Z         'A concept is a reusable unit of user-facing functionality that serves a well-defined and intelligible purpose. Each concept maintains its own state, and interacts with the user (and with other concepts) through atomic actions. Some actions are performed by users; others are output actions that occur spontaneously under the control of the concept.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950153045Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950156455Z         'A concept typically involves objects of several different kinds, holding relationships between them in its state. For example, the *Upvote* concept, whose purpose is to rank items by popularity, maintains a relationship between the items and the users who have approved or disapproved of them. The state of a concept must be sufficiently rich to support the concept‚Äôs behavior; if *Upvote* lacked information about users, for example, it would not be able to prevent double voting. But the concept state should be no richer than it need be: *Upvote* would *not* include anything about a user beyond the user‚Äôs identity, since the user‚Äôs name (for example) plays no role in the concept‚Äôs behavior.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950158966Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950161206Z         'A concept will generally be implemented as a backend service, with its state made persistent using a database. The behavior of the concept is thus captured by an API specification that is similar in many respects to that of conventional backend services. At the same time, because all concepts are user facing, the behavior of a concept is also generally a human behavioral protocol. For example, the *RestaurantReservation* concept whose actions are *reserve*, *cancel*, *seat*, etc., can be viewed by a developer as a backend API with functions/endpoints corresponding to the actions, and to a human user as the pattern of behavior that one engages in for restaurant reservations: reserving, perhaps canceling, being seated on arrival, etc.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950163716Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950166586Z         '## Compared to Concepts in Conceptual Modeling\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950169196Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950172276Z         'In contrast to the way the word is sometimes used in other settings, a concept is not an element in an ontology. In the field of conceptual modeling, a ‚Äúconceptual model‚Äù is often a data model in which the concepts are entities. Richer kinds of conceptual model have been defined that incorporate be- havior, for example, by defining the concepts as objects (or more accurately classes) with their own internal behavior. These approaches do not allow a modular treatment of concepts, however. The behavior associated with a concept typically involves multiple classes of objects, and modifications that involve their relationships to one another. For example, the behavior of the *Upvote* concept is to associate votes with both particular items and with the users who issued the votes (in order to prevent double voting).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950174756Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950177327Z         '## Concept Reuse and Familiarity\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950179737Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950183037Z         'Most concepts are reusable across applications; thus the same *Upvote* concept appears for upvoting comments in the New York Times and for upvoting answers on Stack Overflow. A concept can also be instantiated multiple times within the same application to play different roles.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950185547Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950194838Z         'This archetypal nature of concepts is essential. From the user‚Äôs perspective, it gives the familiarity that makes concepts easy to understand: a user encountering the same context in a new setting brings their understanding of that concept from their experience in previous settings.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950197848Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950208928Z         'From a designer‚Äôs perspective, it allows concepts to be repositories of design knowledge and experience. When a developer implements *Upvote*, even if they can‚Äôt reuse the code of a prior implementation, they can rely on all the discoveries and refinements previously made. Many of these are apparent in the behavior of the concept itself, but others are associated with the implementation, or are subtle enough to need explicit description. The community of designers could develop ‚Äúconcept catalogs‚Äù that capture all this knowledge, along with relationships between concepts (for example, that *Upvote* often relies on the *Session* concept for identifying users, which itself is associated with the *UserAuthentication* concept for authenticating users).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950216619Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950219119Z         '## Concept Independence\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950221509Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950224019Z         'Perhaps the most significant distinguishing feature of concepts, in comparison to other modularity schemes, is their mutual independence. Each concept is defined without reference to any other concepts, and can be understood in isolation.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950226539Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950229579Z         'Early work on mental models established the principle that, in a robust model, the different elements must be independently understandable. The same holds in software: the reason a user can make sense of a new social media app, for example, is that each of the concepts (*Post*, *Comment*, *Upvote*, *Friend*, etc) are not only familiar but also separable, so that understanding one doesn‚Äôt require understanding another.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.95023193Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.95023463Z         'Concept independence lets design scale, because individual concepts can be worked on by different designers or design teams, and brought together later. Reuse requires independence too, because coupling between concepts would prevent a concept from being adopted without also including the concepts it depends on.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.95023719Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.95024027Z         'Polymorphism is key to independence: the designer of a concept should strive to make the concept as free as possible of any assumptions about the content and interpretation of objects passed as action arguments. Even if a *Comment* concept is used within an app only for comments on posts, it should be described as applying comments to arbitrary targets, defined only by their identity.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.95024278Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.95024539Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.95024792Z         '## Separation of concerns\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950250551Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950256421Z         'One of the key advances of concept design is a more effective *separation of concerns* than is typical in software designs. This means that each concept addresses only a single, coherent aspect of the functionality of the application, and does not conflate aspects of functionality that could easily be separated. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950259051Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950261981Z         'In a traditional design, in contrast, concerns are often conflated, especially around objects (or classes). For example, it is common for a *User* class to handle all kinds of functions associated with users: authentication, profiles, naming, choice of communication channels for notification, and more. In a concept design, these would be separated into different concepts: one for authentication, one for profiles, one for naming, one for notification, and so on. The state declaration form makes it easy to associate the appropriate properties or fields with user objects in each concept. For example, the *UserAuthentication* concept may have a state that maps user identifiers to usernames and passwords; the *Profile* concept may map user identifiers to bios and thumbnail images; the *Notification* concept may map user identifiers to phone numbers and email addresses to be used as notification channels.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950270542Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950273242Z         '## Completeness of functionality\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950275702Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950290903Z         `Another key distinction between concept design and traditional design is that concepts are *complete* with respect to their functionality and don't rely on functionality from other concepts. For example, a *Notification* concept that has an action to notify a user cannot "make a call" to an action of an emailing or text messaging context to actually deliver a notification. Instead that functionality would be part of the *Notification* concept itself. It is always possible to separate out some functionality into another concept (and to sync the concepts together to achieve some combined functionality) so long as the concept that remains is still coherent and fulfills all of its functionality without dependencies.\n` +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950294033Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950297033Z         '## Composition by synchronization\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950299423Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950302543Z         "Because concepts are fully independent of one another, they cannot refer to each other or use each other's services. Concepts are therefore composed using *synchronizations* (or *syncs*). A sync is a rule that says that *when* an action happens in one concept, *where* the state of some concept has some property, *then* some action happens in another concept. For example, a sync may say that *when* a post p is deleted (in the *Post* concept, through the occurrence of an action), and *where* c is a comment on the post p (in the *Comment* concept), then comment c is deleted (in the *Comment* concept). This can be written\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950304814Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950307044Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950309514Z         'sync CascadePostDeletion\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950312114Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950315014Z         '\tPost.delete (p)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950317624Z         'where \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950319955Z         '\tin Comment: target of c is p\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950322345Z         'then \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950324915Z         '\tComment.delete (c)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950327625Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950330115Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950332875Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950335545Z         'Not that the syncs is not only causing an action to happen but also providing input arguments to actions (in this case the comment to be deleted).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950338776Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950341676Z         'A sync can have multiple actions in its when and then clauses, and can refer to the state of multiple concepts in the where clause. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950344386Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950346976Z         'Some other examples of how syncs are used:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950350336Z         "- When a user comments on another user's post, the second user is notified\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950353076Z         '- When a user exhibits some good behavior, karma is awarded to them\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950355777Z         '- When a user checks out a shopping cart, their credit card is charged.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950358386Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950361197Z         'Syncs can be used for authentication and authorization. In these case, it is common to represent requests made by a user as actions of a kind of pseudo concept (which is usually called *Request*). For example, a sync might say that if a user requests to delete a post, and the user is the author of the post, then the deletion can go ahead:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950369937Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950372757Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950375067Z         'sync DeletePost\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950377308Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:46.950380008Z         '\tRequest.delet'... 112 more characters,

2025-11-08T01:57:58.682881109Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68288366Z       _id: '019a08f7-ad8c-7e39-9942-addff6e9487c',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68288635Z       title: 'Untitled Note',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682889Z       content: 'eyyy',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68289155Z       owner: '019a0472-7577-7f19-9186-29302646df08',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.6828941Z       date_created: 2025-10-21T22:50:40.908Z,

2025-11-08T01:57:58.68289901Z       folderId: '019a0960-140d-7494-b6cf-1a8e9507ba43'
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68290151Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682904171Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682906651Z       _id: '019a2cde-67d5-7cc7-93f5-cc64980c02f3',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682908921Z       title: 'Cell Membranes & Transport Mechanisms',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682911391Z       content: '# Lecture 5 ‚Äî Cell Membranes & Transport Mechanisms\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682913921Z         '**Course:** BIOL 201 ‚Äî Principles of Cell Biology  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682916761Z         '**Instructor:** Prof. A. Nguyen  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682919122Z         '**Date:** Sept 22\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682921522Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682923932Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682926372Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682928712Z         '## Overview\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682931842Z         'How cells maintain homeostasis through selective permeability, transport proteins, and electrochemical gradients.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682938212Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682940993Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682943603Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682946013Z         '## üîπ Membrane Structure\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682949213Z         '- Fluid mosaic model ‚Üí phospholipid bilayer + embedded proteins  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682951823Z         '- Amphipathic molecules:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682954493Z         '  - **Heads:** hydrophilic (phosphate group)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682957224Z         '  - **Tails:** hydrophobic (fatty acids)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682959734Z         '- Cholesterol:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682962234Z         '  - Stabilizes membrane at high temps\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682964954Z         '  - Prevents packing at low temps ‚Üí maintains fluidity\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682968204Z         '- Membrane asymmetry:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682970684Z         '  - Outer leaflet ‚Üí glycolipids, glycoproteins\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682973274Z         '  - Inner leaflet ‚Üí signaling lipids (e.g., phosphatidylserine)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682975665Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682978355Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682980955Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682983575Z         '## üîπ Passive Transport\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682986115Z         '- **Simple diffusion:** movement down concentration gradient  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682991446Z         '- **Facilitated diffusion:** uses membrane proteins, still passive  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682994196Z         '  - Channel proteins ‚Üí open passage (e.g., aquaporins)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682997016Z         '  - Carrier proteins ‚Üí bind ‚Üí conformational change  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.682999856Z         '- **Osmosis:** water moves toward higher solute concentration  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683002456Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683004906Z         '**Example:**  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683007756Z         '`GLUT1` transports glucose into red blood cells via facilitated diffusion.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683010436Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683019707Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683023357Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683026067Z         '## üîπ Active Transport\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683029348Z         '- Requires **energy (ATP or ion gradient)**  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683032118Z         '- **Primary active transport:**\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683034948Z         '  - Direct ATP hydrolysis  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683037718Z         '  - e.g., Na‚Å∫/K‚Å∫-ATPase ‚Üí pumps 3 Na‚Å∫ out, 2 K‚Å∫ in\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683040128Z         '- **Secondary active transport:**\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683042618Z         '  - Uses energy from another gradient  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683045209Z         '  - e.g., Na‚Å∫/glucose symporter in intestinal cells\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683047838Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683050219Z         '**Mnemonic:**  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683052729Z         '> ‚ÄúPrimary = Power (uses ATP directly)‚Äù  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683055239Z         '> ‚ÄúSecondary = Sneaky (uses another gradient)‚Äù\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683057679Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683060099Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683062539Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683064739Z         '## üîπ Bulk Transport\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68306722Z         '- **Endocytosis:** cell takes in material via vesicles  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68306986Z         '  - Phagocytosis (‚Äúcell eating‚Äù)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68307249Z         '  - Pinocytosis (‚Äúcell drinking‚Äù)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683086501Z         '  - Receptor-mediated endocytosis (specific uptake)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683089951Z         '- **Exocytosis:** vesicles fuse ‚Üí release contents (e.g., neurotransmitters)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683092471Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683095201Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683097941Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683100712Z         '## üîπ Membrane Potential\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683103592Z         '- Established by:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683106122Z         '  - Na‚Å∫/K‚Å∫-ATPase pump\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683109112Z         '  - Leak channels (K‚Å∫ mostly)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683111922Z         '- Creates electrical gradient (inside more negative)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683114962Z         '- Vital for neurons + muscle cells\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683117712Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683120753Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683123223Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683126563Z         '### üß† Exam Tip\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683129123Z         'If energy (ATP) is used directly ‚Üí *primary active transport*  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683131983Z         'If gradient of another molecule is used ‚Üí *secondary active transport*\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683134813Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683137394Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683139944Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683142444Z         '# üåø Lecture 10 ‚Äî Photosynthesis & Energy Conversion\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683145014Z         '**Course:** BIOL 210 ‚Äî Plant Physiology  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683147544Z         '**Instructor:** Dr. Chen  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683150074Z         '**Date:** Oct 4\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683152304Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683154735Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683156924Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683159235Z         '## Overview\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683161745Z         'Conversion of solar ‚Üí chemical energy in chloroplasts.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683164295Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683166715Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683187186Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683190126Z         '## üîπ Two Main Stages\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683192497Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683194947Z         '### 1Ô∏è‚É£ Light Reactions (Thylakoid Membrane)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683197367Z         '- Input: light + H‚ÇÇO  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683199717Z         '- Output: ATP + NADPH + O‚ÇÇ  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683202017Z         '- **Steps:**\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683204667Z         '  - Photon excites chlorophyll in PSII\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683207387Z         '  - Water splitting ‚Üí O‚ÇÇ + e‚Åª + H‚Å∫ (via oxygen-evolving complex)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683209807Z         '  - e‚Åª passed down ETC ‚Üí ATP (chemiosmosis)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683212318Z         '  - PSI re-energizes e‚Åª ‚Üí NADP‚Å∫ ‚Üí NADPH\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683215018Z         '- **Location:** thylakoid membrane\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683217628Z         '- **Products:** ATP & NADPH ‚Üí used in Calvin Cycle\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683220228Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683222978Z         '### 2Ô∏è‚É£ Calvin Cycle (Stroma)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683225768Z         '- Input: CO‚ÇÇ + ATP + NADPH  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683228139Z         '- Output: G3P (‚Üí glucose)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683230468Z         '- **Phases:**\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683233139Z         '  1. **Carbon fixation:** RuBisCO fixes CO‚ÇÇ ‚Üí 3-PGA  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683236169Z         '  2. **Reduction:** ATP + NADPH reduce 3-PGA ‚Üí G3P  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683242189Z         '  3. **Regeneration:** some G3P ‚Üí regenerate RuBP  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683244799Z         '- **Location:** stroma\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68324734Z         '- **Key enzyme:** RuBisCO (slow but crucial)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68325005Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68325262Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68325504Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68325748Z         '## üîπ Photorespiration\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68325997Z         '- Occurs when O‚ÇÇ binds to RuBisCO instead of CO‚ÇÇ  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68326258Z         '- Wastes energy, releases CO‚ÇÇ  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683265021Z         '- More likely under:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68326747Z         '  - High temps\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683270351Z         '  - Low CO‚ÇÇ levels\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683273671Z         '- **C4 & CAM plants** reduce this via spatial/temporal CO‚ÇÇ concentration mechanisms.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683276111Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683278501Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683281081Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683283762Z         '## üîπ Energy Summary Table\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683286462Z         '| Stage             | Location          | Inputs                 | Outputs                 |\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683289102Z         '|-------------------|------------------|------------------------|--------------------------|\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683292032Z         '| Light Reactions   | Thylakoid Membrane | Light, H‚ÇÇO, ADP, NADP‚Å∫ | O‚ÇÇ, ATP, NADPH          |\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683295022Z         '| Calvin Cycle      | Stroma             | CO‚ÇÇ, ATP, NADPH        | G3P, ADP, NADP‚Å∫         |\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683297672Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683300672Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683303492Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683306003Z         '### üß† Fun Fact\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683307883Z         'Plants reflect green light because chlorophyll *a* and *b* absorb mostly red and blue wavelengths.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683314313Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683316153Z         '\n',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683318023Z       owner: '019a0472-7577-7f19-9186-29302646df08',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683319704Z       date_created: 2025-10-28T22:09:24.437Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683321464Z       last_modified: 2025-10-28T22:09:37.802Z
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683323174Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683324954Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683326694Z       _id: '019a2cdf-4953-7d9d-b0aa-ef88b6404d47',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683328434Z       title: 'Introduction to Biology & The Scientific Method',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683330214Z       content: '# Lecture 1 ‚Äî Introduction to Biology & The Scientific Method\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683331924Z         '**Course:** BIOL 101 ‚Äî Foundations of Biology  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683333664Z         '**Instructor:** Dr. L. Patel  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683335384Z         '**Date:** Sept 2\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683337084Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683338774Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683340585Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683342235Z         '## Overview\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683344025Z         'Biology = study of living organisms and their interactions with the environment.  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683356735Z         'Goal: understand how life is organized, functions, evolves, and sustains itself.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683358866Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683360566Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683362256Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683364086Z         '## üîπ Characteristics of Life\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683365776Z         '1. Cellular organization  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683367496Z         '2. Metabolism (energy use)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683369176Z         '3. Homeostasis (internal balance)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683370846Z         '4. Growth & development  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683372556Z         '5. Reproduction  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683374316Z         '6. Response to stimuli  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683375996Z         '7. Evolutionary adaptation  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683377707Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683379427Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683381097Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683382807Z         '## üîπ Levels of Biological Organization\n',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683384487Z       owner: '019a0472-7577-7f19-9186-29302646df08',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683386177Z       date_created: 2025-10-28T22:10:22.163Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683387867Z       last_modified: 2025-10-28T22:10:44.479Z
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683389577Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683391327Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683393037Z       _id: '019a2cdf-fcb8-7d74-b8f8-126be43cbf12',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683394728Z       title: 'DNA Structure & Replication',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683396428Z       content: '# Lecture 2 ‚Äî DNA Structure & Replication\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683398198Z         '**Course:** BIOL 110 ‚Äî Molecular Biology  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683399868Z         '**Instructor:** Prof. A. Rivera  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683401608Z         '**Date:** Sept 9\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683403318Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683406478Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683408208Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683409898Z         '## Overview\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683411758Z         'DNA = hereditary material carrying genetic instructions.  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683413529Z         'Replication ensures identical transmission during cell division.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683415229Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683416919Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683422609Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683424389Z         '## üîπ DNA Structure\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683428409Z         '- Double helix (Watson & Crick, 1953)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68343021Z         '- Nucleotides:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683432259Z         '  - **Sugar:** deoxyribose  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68343396Z         '  - **Phosphate group**\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68343567Z         '  - **Nitrogenous base:** A, T, C, G  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68343736Z         '- Base pairing:  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68343906Z         '  - A ‚Üî T (2 hydrogen bonds)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68344083Z         '  - C ‚Üî G (3 hydrogen bonds)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68344252Z         '- Antiparallel strands:  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68344423Z         '  - 5‚Äô ‚Üí 3‚Äô and 3‚Äô ‚Üí 5‚Äô\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68344591Z         '- Complementarity allows accurate replication\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68344762Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683451441Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683453191Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683454891Z         '## üîπ DNA Replication (Semi-conservative)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683456621Z         '- Each daughter DNA = 1 old + 1 new strand  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683458331Z         '- **Enzymes involved:**\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683460021Z         '  - **Helicase:** unwinds DNA  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683461731Z         '  - **Primase:** adds RNA primer  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683463451Z         '  - **DNA polymerase:** adds nucleotides (5‚Äô‚Üí3‚Äô)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683465201Z         '  - **Ligase:** seals Okazaki fragments on lagging strand  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683466912Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683468592Z         '**Leading strand:** continuous synthesis  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683470372Z         '**Lagging strand:** discontinuous (Okazaki fragments)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683472092Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683473792Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683475482Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683477162Z         '## üîπ Origins of Replication\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683478872Z         '- Prokaryotes ‚Üí single origin  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683480602Z         '- Eukaryotes ‚Üí multiple origins  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683482272Z         '- Bidirectional replication forks\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683484033Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683485733Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683487402Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683489093Z         '## üîπ Proofreading & Repair\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683490803Z         '- DNA polymerase has 3‚Äô‚Üí5‚Äô exonuclease activity  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683492483Z         '- Mismatch repair fixes post-replication errors  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683494253Z         '- UV damage ‚Üí thymine dimers ‚Üí repaired by photolyase or excision repair\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683495983Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683497713Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683499393Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683501103Z         '### üß† Quick Fact\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683502954Z         'Average human cell ‚Üí ~6 billion base pairs; replication errors ‚âà 1 in 10‚Åπ bp (after proofreading)\n',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683504703Z       owner: '019a0472-7577-7f19-9186-29302646df08',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683506374Z       date_created: 2025-10-28T22:11:08.088Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683508064Z       last_modified: 2025-10-28T22:11:15.687Z
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683509754Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683511474Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683513154Z       _id: '019a2ce0-77d7-7819-a4e2-47f0909e6cbe',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683517624Z       title: 'Nervous System & Neuron Function',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683519384Z       content: '# Lecture 3 ‚Äî Nervous System & Neuron Function\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683521084Z         '**Course:** BIOL 205 ‚Äî Human Physiology  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683522764Z         '**Instructor:** Dr. C. Morales  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683524485Z         '**Date:** Sept 16\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683526175Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683527915Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683529585Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683531255Z         '## Overview\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683533025Z         'Nervous system = communication network controlling body function and behavior.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683534795Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683536465Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683538145Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683539836Z         '## üîπ Organization\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683541585Z         '- **Central nervous system (CNS):** brain + spinal cord  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683543596Z         '- **Peripheral nervous system (PNS):** nerves connecting CNS to body  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683545286Z         '  - Somatic (voluntary)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683552856Z         '  - Autonomic (involuntary) ‚Üí sympathetic & parasympathetic divisions\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683554766Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683556496Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683558186Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683559897Z         '## üîπ Neuron Structure\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683561617Z         '- **Cell body (soma)** ‚Äî nucleus, metabolic center  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683563317Z         '- **Dendrites** ‚Äî receive input  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683565047Z         '- **Axon** ‚Äî transmits signals  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683567077Z         '- **Myelin sheath** ‚Äî insulation (formed by Schwann or oligodendrocytes)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683568797Z         '- **Synaptic terminals** ‚Äî neurotransmitter release\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683570487Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683572167Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683573877Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683575558Z         '## üîπ Resting Membrane Potential\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683577287Z         '- Inside cell ‚âà -70 mV  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683578968Z         '- Maintained by:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683580678Z         '  - Na‚Å∫/K‚Å∫ ATPase (3 Na‚Å∫ out, 2 K‚Å∫ in)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683582348Z         '  - K‚Å∫ leak channels  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683584048Z         '- Polarized = more negative inside\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683586418Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683588398Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683590078Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683591788Z         '## üîπ Action Potential\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683593568Z         '1. Stimulus ‚Üí depolarization to threshold (-55 mV)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683595288Z         '2. Voltage-gated Na‚Å∫ channels open ‚Üí Na‚Å∫ influx  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683596979Z         '3. Rapid depolarization (+30 mV)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683598779Z         '4. Na‚Å∫ channels inactivate, K‚Å∫ channels open ‚Üí repolarization  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683600489Z         '5. Hyperpolarization ‚Üí refractory period  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683602239Z         '6. Resting potential restored\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683603929Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683605609Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683607279Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683608959Z         '## üîπ Synaptic Transmission\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68361378Z         '- AP arrives at terminal ‚Üí Ca¬≤‚Å∫ influx ‚Üí vesicles fuse  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68361554Z         '- Neurotransmitters released into synaptic cleft  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68361726Z         '- Bind to receptors on postsynaptic cell ‚Üí new potential generated  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683619Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68362071Z         '**Common neurotransmitters:**\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68362239Z         '- Acetylcholine (ACh)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68362414Z         '- Dopamine\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68362586Z         '- Serotonin\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68362758Z         '- GABA\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68362938Z         '- Glutamate\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683631101Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68363283Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683634521Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683636221Z         '### üß† Summary\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683637991Z         'Neurons = excitable cells transmitting electrical ‚Üí chemical ‚Üí electrical signals.\n',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683639711Z       owner: '019a0472-7577-7f19-9186-29302646df08',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683642891Z       date_created: 2025-10-28T22:11:39.607Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683645131Z       last_modified: 2025-10-28T22:11:45.857Z
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683646861Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683648581Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683650291Z       _id: '019a2ce1-e262-7906-8bf5-33de1db7ebe1',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683652452Z       title: 'Limits and Continuity',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683654192Z       content: '# Lecture 1 ‚Äî Limits and Continuity\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683655862Z         'Course: MATH 201 ‚Äî Calculus I  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683657602Z         'Instructor: Prof. T. Hsu  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683659302Z         'Date: Sept 5\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683661002Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683662712Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683664392Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683666192Z         '## Overview\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683667923Z         'Limits describe the behavior of a function as x approaches a certain point.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683669632Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683671323Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683673003Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683674693Z         '## Limit Definition\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683676423Z         'lim_{x ‚Üí a} f(x) = L  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683678213Z         'means that f(x) can be made arbitrarily close to L by taking x sufficiently close to a (but not equal to a).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683679933Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683681773Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683683473Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683685173Z         '## Evaluating Limits\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683686893Z         '1. Direct substitution ‚Äî works when f is continuous at a.  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683688593Z         '   Example: lim_{x‚Üí3} (2x + 1) = 7  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683690324Z         '2. Factoring ‚Äî used to simplify 0/0 forms.  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683692024Z         '   Example: lim_{x‚Üí2} (x¬≤ - 4)/(x - 2)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683693764Z         '   ‚Üí factor numerator ‚Üí (x + 2)(x - 2)/(x - 2) ‚Üí limit = 4  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683695464Z         '3. Rationalizing ‚Äî multiply by conjugate to remove radicals.  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683697174Z         '   Example: lim_{x‚Üí0} (‚àö(x + 1) - 1)/x = 1/2  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683699124Z         '4. Special limits:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683700904Z         '   - lim_{x‚Üí0} (sin x)/x = 1  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683702584Z         '   - lim_{x‚Üí‚àû} (1 + 1/x)^x = e\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683707045Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683726866Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683735276Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683737716Z         '## One-Sided Limits and Continuity\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683740156Z         'Left-hand limit: lim_{x‚Üía^-} f(x)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683742356Z         'Right-hand limit: lim_{x‚Üía^+} f(x)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683744667Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683747127Z         'f is continuous at x = a if:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683749807Z         '1. f(a) is defined  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683752537Z         '2. lim_{x‚Üía} f(x) exists  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683755777Z         '3. lim_{x‚Üía} f(x) = f(a)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683757807Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683759528Z         'Example:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683761288Z         'f(x) = { x¬≤, x ‚â§ 2  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683762958Z         '         3x - 2, x > 2 }\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683764648Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683766418Z         'lim_{x‚Üí2^-} f(x) = 4  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683768148Z         'lim_{x‚Üí2^+} f(x) = 4  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683771448Z         'f(2) = 4  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683779318Z         '‚Üí Continuous at x = 2\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683781199Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683782929Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683784649Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683786499Z         '## Key Idea\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683788309Z         `Continuity ensures no "jumps" or "holes" in a function's graph.\n`,
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683790059Z       owner: '019a0472-7577-7f19-9186-29302646df08',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683791759Z       date_created: 2025-10-28T22:13:12.418Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683793629Z       last_modified: 2025-10-28T22:13:15.031Z
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68379529Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68379701Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68379873Z       _id: '019a2ce2-13a8-78a7-a3f0-f81a056baa1c',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.6838005Z       title: 'Derivatives and Differentiation Rules',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68380225Z       content: '# Lecture 2 ‚Äî Derivatives and Differentiation Rules\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68380402Z         'Course: MATH 201 ‚Äî Calculus I  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68380572Z         'Instructor: Prof. T. Hsu  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68380741Z         'Date: Sept 8\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68380917Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68381087Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68381256Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68381452Z         '## Overview\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683816231Z         'The derivative measures how a function changes ‚Äî its instantaneous rate of change.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683817921Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683819661Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683821361Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683823091Z         '## Derivative Definition\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683824811Z         "f'(x) = lim_{h‚Üí0} [f(x + h) - f(x)] / h\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683826501Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683828221Z         'Example:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683829951Z         'f(x) = x¬≤  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683831652Z         "‚Üí f'(x) = lim_{h‚Üí0} [(x + h)¬≤ - x¬≤] / h  \n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683833381Z         '= lim_{h‚Üí0} (2xh + h¬≤)/h  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683835082Z         '= 2x\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683836792Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683838472Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683840142Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683841862Z         '## Basic Rules\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683847662Z         "- Constant rule: (c)' = 0  \n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683849462Z         "- Power rule: (x^n)' = n¬∑x^(n - 1)  \n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683851142Z         "- Sum rule: (f + g)' = f' + g'  \n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683852813Z         "- Difference rule: (f - g)' = f' - g'  \n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683854483Z         "- Product rule: (fg)' = f'g + fg'  \n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683856163Z         "- Quotient rule: (f/g)' = (f'g - fg') / g¬≤  \n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683857863Z         "- Chain rule: (f(g(x)))' = f'(g(x)) * g'(x)\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683859623Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683861323Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683863003Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683864693Z         '## Examples\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683866433Z         '1. f(x) = 3x¬≥ - 2x + 5  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683868163Z         "   ‚Üí f'(x) = 9x¬≤ - 2  \n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683869874Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683871554Z         '2. f(x) = (x¬≤ + 1)(x¬≥ - 4)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683873284Z         "   ‚Üí f'(x) = 2x(x¬≥ - 4) + 3x¬≤(x¬≤ + 1)\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683874974Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683876704Z         '3. f(x) = sin(3x)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683878364Z         "   ‚Üí f'(x) = 3cos(3x)\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683880064Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683881794Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683883494Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683885174Z         '## Applications\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683886895Z         "- Slope of tangent line at a point: m = f'(a)  \n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683888575Z         '- Instantaneous velocity = derivative of position  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683890765Z         '- Marginal cost/revenue in economics = derivative of total cost/revenue\n',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683893115Z       owner: '019a0472-7577-7f19-9186-29302646df08',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683894835Z       date_created: 2025-10-28T22:13:25.032Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683896515Z       last_modified: 2025-10-28T22:13:30.550Z
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683898195Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683899885Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683901605Z       _id: '019a2ce2-7a90-7104-a6c5-107df3b04882',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683903295Z       title: 'Introduction to Programming Concepts',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683905005Z       content: '# Lecture 3 ‚Äî Introduction to Programming Concepts\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683906705Z         'Course: CS 101 ‚Äî Computer Science Fundamentals  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683908396Z         'Instructor: Dr. M. Zhao  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683910096Z         'Date: Sept 10\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683911806Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683913486Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683915216Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683916906Z         '## Overview\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683918656Z         'Programming = giving a computer step-by-step instructions to perform tasks.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683920356Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683922026Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683923706Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683925397Z         '## Components of a Program\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683927067Z         '1. **Variables:** store data values.  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683928807Z         '   Example (Python):  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683930547Z         '   x = 10  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683932277Z         '   name = "Alice"\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683933977Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683935707Z         '2. **Data types:** int, float, string, bool, list, dict  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683937427Z         '   Example:  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683941927Z         '   price = 19.99  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683943747Z         '   is_valid = True  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683945498Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683947218Z         '3. **Control flow:**\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683949208Z         '   - if / else  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683950958Z         '   - for and while loops  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683952628Z         '   - break and continue  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683954328Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683956008Z         'Example:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683957738Z         'Start writing your note...',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683959508Z       owner: '019a0472-7577-7f19-9186-29302646df08',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683961208Z       date_created: 2025-10-28T22:13:51.376Z,
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683962948Z       last_modified: 2025-10-28T22:13:53.871Z
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683964669Z     },
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683966379Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683968059Z       _id: '019a2cf9-4339-7ec6-a840-fe04245db430',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683969749Z       title: 'Concept',
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683971449Z       content: '# Why Concept Design?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.683973189Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68398146Z         'Concept design is a new approach to software development that attempts to find greater modularity in the structuring of the functionality of applications. The key idea is to break the functionality down into separable, modular services called *concepts*, each of which can be specified, implemented and understood separately -- by users and by developers. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68398338Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68398511Z         'The advantages of concept design include:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68398716Z         '- Improved separation of concerns resulting in simpler and more robust design and implementation;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68398949Z         '- Greater recognition of reusable behaviors, so reduced work for designers and developers and more familiar interactions for users;\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68399215Z         '- Improved focus on the purposes and motivations of the functionality, since each concept is closely targeted at delivering a particular function of value in the context of the larger app.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.6839939Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68399565Z         '## What is a concept?\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68399737Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68399913Z         'A concept is a reusable unit of user-facing functionality that serves a well-defined and intelligible purpose. Each concept maintains its own state, and interacts with the user (and with other concepts) through atomic actions. Some actions are performed by users; others are output actions that occur spontaneously under the control of the concept.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684000861Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684003181Z         'A concept typically involves objects of several different kinds, holding relationships between them in its state. For example, the *Upvote* concept, whose purpose is to rank items by popularity, maintains a relationship between the items and the users who have approved or disapproved of them. The state of a concept must be sufficiently rich to support the concept‚Äôs behavior; if *Upvote* lacked information about users, for example, it would not be able to prevent double voting. But the concept state should be no richer than it need be: *Upvote* would *not* include anything about a user beyond the user‚Äôs identity, since the user‚Äôs name (for example) plays no role in the concept‚Äôs behavior.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684004941Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684006671Z         'A concept will generally be implemented as a backend service, with its state made persistent using a database. The behavior of the concept is thus captured by an API specification that is similar in many respects to that of conventional backend services. At the same time, because all concepts are user facing, the behavior of a concept is also generally a human behavioral protocol. For example, the *RestaurantReservation* concept whose actions are *reserve*, *cancel*, *seat*, etc., can be viewed by a developer as a backend API with functions/endpoints corresponding to the actions, and to a human user as the pattern of behavior that one engages in for restaurant reservations: reserving, perhaps canceling, being seated on arrival, etc.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684011251Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684013011Z         '## Compared to Concepts in Conceptual Modeling\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684014702Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684018932Z         'In contrast to the way the word is sometimes used in other settings, a concept is not an element in an ontology. In the field of conceptual modeling, a ‚Äúconceptual model‚Äù is often a data model in which the concepts are entities. Richer kinds of conceptual model have been defined that incorporate be- havior, for example, by defining the concepts as objects (or more accurately classes) with their own internal behavior. These approaches do not allow a modular treatment of concepts, however. The behavior associated with a concept typically involves multiple classes of objects, and modifications that involve their relationships to one another. For example, the behavior of the *Upvote* concept is to associate votes with both particular items and with the users who issued the votes (in order to prevent double voting).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684020712Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684023362Z         '## Concept Reuse and Familiarity\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684025092Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684047263Z         'Most concepts are reusable across applications; thus the same *Upvote* concept appears for upvoting comments in the New York Times and for upvoting answers on Stack Overflow. A concept can also be instantiated multiple times within the same application to play different roles.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684055744Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684066494Z         'This archetypal nature of concepts is essential. From the user‚Äôs perspective, it gives the familiarity that makes concepts easy to understand: a user encountering the same context in a new setting brings their understanding of that concept from their experience in previous settings.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684069794Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684074285Z         'From a designer‚Äôs perspective, it allows concepts to be repositories of design knowledge and experience. When a developer implements *Upvote*, even if they can‚Äôt reuse the code of a prior implementation, they can rely on all the discoveries and refinements previously made. Many of these are apparent in the behavior of the concept itself, but others are associated with the implementation, or are subtle enough to need explicit description. The community of designers could develop ‚Äúconcept catalogs‚Äù that capture all this knowledge, along with relationships between concepts (for example, that *Upvote* often relies on the *Session* concept for identifying users, which itself is associated with the *UserAuthentication* concept for authenticating users).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684077105Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684080555Z         '## Concept Independence\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684082525Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684084985Z         'Perhaps the most significant distinguishing feature of concepts, in comparison to other modularity schemes, is their mutual independence. Each concept is defined without reference to any other concepts, and can be understood in isolation.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684086705Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684098846Z         'Early work on mental models established the principle that, in a robust model, the different elements must be independently understandable. The same holds in software: the reason a user can make sense of a new social media app, for example, is that each of the concepts (*Post*, *Comment*, *Upvote*, *Friend*, etc) are not only familiar but also separable, so that understanding one doesn‚Äôt require understanding another.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684100716Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684103956Z         'Concept independence lets design scale, because individual concepts can be worked on by different designers or design teams, and brought together later. Reuse requires independence too, because coupling between concepts would prevent a concept from being adopted without also including the concepts it depends on.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684105686Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684108636Z         'Polymorphism is key to independence: the designer of a concept should strive to make the concept as free as possible of any assumptions about the content and interpretation of objects passed as action arguments. Even if a *Comment* concept is used within an app only for comments on posts, it should be described as applying comments to arbitrary targets, defined only by their identity.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684110717Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684112447Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684114157Z         '## Separation of concerns\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684115937Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684117637Z         'One of the key advances of concept design is a more effective *separation of concerns* than is typical in software designs. This means that each concept addresses only a single, coherent aspect of the functionality of the application, and does not conflate aspects of functionality that could easily be separated. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684119457Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684122297Z         'In a traditional design, in contrast, concerns are often conflated, especially around objects (or classes). For example, it is common for a *User* class to handle all kinds of functions associated with users: authentication, profiles, naming, choice of communication channels for notification, and more. In a concept design, these would be separated into different concepts: one for authentication, one for profiles, one for naming, one for notification, and so on. The state declaration form makes it easy to associate the appropriate properties or fields with user objects in each concept. For example, the *UserAuthentication* concept may have a state that maps user identifiers to usernames and passwords; the *Profile* concept may map user identifiers to bios and thumbnail images; the *Notification* concept may map user identifiers to phone numbers and email addresses to be used as notification channels.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684124157Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684125917Z         '## Completeness of functionality\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684127628Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684135968Z         `Another key distinction between concept design and traditional design is that concepts are *complete* with respect to their functionality and don't rely on functionality from other concepts. For example, a *Notification* concept that has an action to notify a user cannot "make a call" to an action of an emailing or text messaging context to actually deliver a notification. Instead that functionality would be part of the *Notification* concept itself. It is always possible to separate out some functionality into another concept (and to sync the concepts together to achieve some combined functionality) so long as the concept that remains is still coherent and fulfills all of its functionality without dependencies.\n` +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684137888Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684145889Z         '## Composition by synchronization\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684148679Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684152709Z         "Because concepts are fully independent of one another, they cannot refer to each other or use each other's services. Concepts are therefore composed using *synchronizations* (or *syncs*). A sync is a rule that says that *when* an action happens in one concept, *where* the state of some concept has some property, *then* some action happens in another concept. For example, a sync may say that *when* a post p is deleted (in the *Post* concept, through the occurrence of an action), and *where* c is a comment on the post p (in the *Comment* concept), then comment c is deleted (in the *Comment* concept). This can be written\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684155589Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684158839Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68416163Z         'sync CascadePostDeletion\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.6841645Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68416832Z         '\tPost.delete (p)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68417135Z         'where \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68417393Z         '\tin Comment: target of c is p\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68417586Z         'then \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.68417764Z         '\tComment.delete (c)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684179311Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684181071Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684182761Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684185211Z         'Not that the syncs is not only causing an action to happen but also providing input arguments to actions (in this case the comment to be deleted).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684187051Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684188791Z         'A sync can have multiple actions in its when and then clauses, and can refer to the state of multiple concepts in the where clause. \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684190541Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684192851Z         'Some other examples of how syncs are used:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684195451Z         "- When a user comments on another user's post, the second user is notified\n" +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684197191Z         '- When a user exhibits some good behavior, karma is awarded to them\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684198852Z         '- When a user checks out a shopping cart, their credit card is charged.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684200532Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684203022Z         'Syncs can be used for authentication and authorization. In these case, it is common to represent requests made by a user as actions of a kind of pseudo concept (which is usually called *Request*). For example, a sync might say that if a user requests to delete a post, and the user is the author of the post, then the deletion can go ahead:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684204762Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684206452Z         '```\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684208322Z         'sync DeletePost\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684210032Z         'when \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.684211772Z         '\tRequest.delet'... 110 more characters,

2025-11-08T01:57:58.684776753Z         'The Cool Notes were a British pop-funk group who had a string of chart hits in the UK between 1984 and 1986. The band, which formed in South London,[1] consisted of seven members of both vocal and instrumental talent. They are best known for their UK number 11 hit, "Spend the Night".[2]\n' +

2025-11-08T01:57:58.685008006Z         'Pizza Hut, LLC[3] is an American multinational pizza restaurant chain and international franchise founded in 1958 in Wichita, Kansas, by brothers Dan and Frank Carney. The chain, headquartered in Plano, Texas, operates 19,866 restaurants worldwide as of 2023.[4]\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685009736Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685018686Z         'While studying at Wichita State University, the Carneys opened their first location, which quickly expanded to six outlets within a year. The brand began franchising in 1959, and its distinctive building style was designed by Chicago architect George Lindstrom in 1963. Pizza Hut experienced significant growth, including the acquisition by PepsiCo in 1977, followed by a spin-off into Tricon Global Restaurants, Inc., later renamed Yum! Brands[5] in 2002, who are the current owners.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685020616Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685022526Z         'Pizza Hut introduced PizzaNet in 1994, an early internet ordering experiment, and continued innovation with offerings like stuffed crust pizza introduced in 1995. Pizza Hut has adapted its model to include various restaurant formats, including the family-style dine-in locations, carry-out, and hybrid locations. It has ventured into international markets, tailoring its menu to local tastes. The brand faced challenges, including the closure of numerous dine-in locations in the United States and adjustments to its franchise operations. Despite these hurdles, Pizza Hut remains a significant player in the global fast-food industry, known for its innovative products and marketing strategies.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685024257Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685025947Z         'History\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685027677Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685029507Z         'The first Pizza Hut opened on May 31, 1958, in Wichita, Kansas.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685031287Z         'Pizza Hut was launched on May 31, 1958,[6] by two brothers, Dan and Frank Carney, both Wichita State students, as a single location in Wichita, Kansas.[7] Six months later they opened a second outlet, and within a year they were operating six locations.[8] The brothers began franchising in 1959.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685032997Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685034737Z         'One early employee was future Pro Football Hall of Fame head coach Bill Parcells, who had worked for the company while a college student and football player at Wichita State University. Parcells was considering a franchise for a career (as well as law school), but instead chose to enter coaching, eventually becoming a head coach in the National Football League.[9]\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685036457Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685043858Z         'The iconic Pizza Hut building style with the distinctive red roof was introduced in 1969, and was later incorporated into the corporate logo.[10][11][8]\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685045618Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685047388Z         'PepsiCo acquired Pizza Hut in November 1977.[12][13] On May 30, 1997, PepsiCo spun off Pizza Hut, along with Taco Bell and Kentucky Fried Chicken, into a new company named Tricon Global Restaurants, Inc. The company assumed the name of Yum! Brands on May 22, 2002.[14][15]\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685050368Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685052698Z         'The first Pizza Hut restaurant east of the Mississippi River was opened in Athens, Ohio, in 1966 by Lawrence Berberick and Gary Meyers.[16]\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:58.685054468Z         '\n' +

2025-11-08T01:57:59.272485222Z     {
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272486912Z       _id: '019a2ce1-e262-7906-8bf5-33de1db7ebe1',
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272488612Z       title: 'Limits and Continuity',
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272490372Z       content: '# Lecture 1 ‚Äî Limits and Continuity\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272492102Z         'Course: MATH 201 ‚Äî Calculus I  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272493813Z         'Instructor: Prof. T. Hsu  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272495502Z         'Date: Sept 5\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272497213Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272498973Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272500653Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272502393Z         '## Overview\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272504183Z         'Limits describe the behavior of a function as x approaches a certain point.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272505883Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272507543Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272509223Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272510913Z         '## Limit Definition\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272513503Z         'lim_{x ‚Üí a} f(x) = L  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272516494Z         'means that f(x) can be made arbitrarily close to L by taking x sufficiently close to a (but not equal to a).\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272519744Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272522404Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272525204Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272527784Z         '## Evaluating Limits\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272530544Z         '1. Direct substitution ‚Äî works when f is continuous at a.  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272533044Z         '   Example: lim_{x‚Üí3} (2x + 1) = 7  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272535835Z         '2. Factoring ‚Äî used to simplify 0/0 forms.  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272542615Z         '   Example: lim_{x‚Üí2} (x¬≤ - 4)/(x - 2)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272544445Z         '   ‚Üí factor numerator ‚Üí (x + 2)(x - 2)/(x - 2) ‚Üí limit = 4  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272546145Z         '3. Rationalizing ‚Äî multiply by conjugate to remove radicals.  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272547855Z         '   Example: lim_{x‚Üí0} (‚àö(x + 1) - 1)/x = 1/2  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272549545Z         '4. Special limits:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272551265Z         '   - lim_{x‚Üí0} (sin x)/x = 1  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272552946Z         '   - lim_{x‚Üí‚àû} (1 + 1/x)^x = e\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272554636Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272556316Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272558036Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272559786Z         '## One-Sided Limits and Continuity\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272561516Z         'Left-hand limit: lim_{x‚Üía^-} f(x)  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272563236Z         'Right-hand limit: lim_{x‚Üía^+} f(x)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272564936Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272566946Z         'f is continuous at x = a if:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272568637Z         '1. f(a) is defined  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272570347Z         '2. lim_{x‚Üía} f(x) exists  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272572107Z         '3. lim_{x‚Üía} f(x) = f(a)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272573807Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272575497Z         'Example:\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272577247Z         'f(x) = { x¬≤, x ‚â§ 2  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272578927Z         '         3x - 2, x > 2 }\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272580597Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272582277Z         'lim_{x‚Üí2^-} f(x) = 4  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272583957Z         'lim_{x‚Üí2^+} f(x) = 4  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272585698Z         'f(2) = 4  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272594398Z         '‚Üí Continuous at x = 2\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272596268Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272597948Z         '---\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272599978Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272602698Z         '## Key Idea\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272605748Z         `Continuity ensures no "jumps" or "holes" in a function's graph.\n`,
2025-11-08T01:57:59.272608439Z       owner: '019a0472-7577-7f19-9186-29302646df08',

2025-11-08T01:57:59.272619299Z     {

2025-11-08T01:57:59.272624689Z       title: 'Derivatives and Differentiation Rules',
2025-11-08T01:57:59.27262654Z       content: '# Lecture 2 ‚Äî Derivatives and Differentiation Rules\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.27262829Z         'Course: MATH 201 ‚Äî Calculus I  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.27262998Z         'Instructor: Prof. T. Hsu  \n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.27263173Z         'Date: Sept 8\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464593321Z         'Industry\tRestaurant\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464595061Z         'Genre\tPizzeria\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464596771Z         'Fast food\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464598541Z         'Founded\tMay 31, 1958; 67 years ago Wichita, Kansas, U.S.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464600242Z         'Founders\t\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464601931Z         'Dan Carney\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464603632Z         'Frank Carney\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464605342Z         'Headquarters\t\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464607042Z         '7100 Corporate Dr., Plano, Texas (USA)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464608832Z         'Elstree Way, Borehamwood Hertfordshire (UK)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464610542Z         'Number of locations\t19,866 restaurants worldwide (2023)\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464612262Z         'Area served\tWorldwide\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464613982Z         'Key people\tAaron Powell (president, Pizza Hut International)[1]\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464615722Z         'Products\t\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464618512Z         'Pizzapan pizzapastachicken wingsbreadsticks\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464621523Z         'Services\tFranchising\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464624173Z         'Revenue\tIncrease US$1.091 billion (2016)[2]\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464626953Z         'Number of employees\tAbout 350,000[2]\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464629663Z         'Parent\tYum! Brands\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464640024Z         'Website\tpizzahut.com\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464643484Z         'Pizza Hut, LLC[3] is an American multinational pizza restaurant chain and international franchise founded in 1958 in Wichita, Kansas, by brothers Dan and Frank Carney. The chain, headquartered in Plano, Texas, operates 19,866 restaurants worldwide as of 2023.[4]\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464646154Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464649724Z         'While studying at Wichita State University, the Carneys opened their first location, which quickly expanded to six outlets within a year. The brand began franchising in 1959, and its distinctive building style was designed by Chicago architect George Lindstrom in 1963. Pizza Hut experienced significant growth, including the acquisition by PepsiCo in 1977, followed by a spin-off into Tricon Global Restaurants, Inc., later renamed Yum! Brands[5] in 2002, who are the current owners.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464652644Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464654674Z         'Pizza Hut introduced PizzaNet in 1994, an early internet ordering experiment, and continued innovation with offerings like stuffed crust pizza introduced in 1995. Pizza Hut has adapted its model to include various restaurant formats, including the family-style dine-in locations, carry-out, and hybrid locations. It has ventured into international markets, tailoring its menu to local tastes. The brand faced challenges, including the closure of numerous dine-in locations in the United States and adjustments to its franchise operations. Despite these hurdles, Pizza Hut remains a significant player in the global fast-food industry, known for its innovative products and marketing strategies.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464656485Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464658155Z         'History\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464659845Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464661665Z         'The first Pizza Hut opened on May 31, 1958, in Wichita, Kansas.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464663455Z         'Pizza Hut was launched on May 31, 1958,[6] by two brothers, Dan and Frank Carney, both Wichita State students, as a single location in Wichita, Kansas.[7] Six months later they opened a second outlet, and within a year they were operating six locations.[8] The brothers began franchising in 1959.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464669185Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464671165Z         'One early employee was future Pro Football Hall of Fame head coach Bill Parcells, who had worked for the company while a college student and football player at Wichita State University. Parcells was considering a franchise for a career (as well as law school), but instead chose to enter coaching, eventually becoming a head coach in the National Football League.[9]\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464672926Z         '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:57:59.464675135Z         'The iconic Pizza Hut building style with the distinctive red roof was introduced in 1969, and was later incorporated into the corporate logo.[10][11][8]\n' +
2025-11-08T01:58:00.170887195Z }

2025-11-08T01:58:00.767631488Z   summary: '*   **Origins and Growth**: Founded in 1958, Pizza Hut rapidly expanded from a single location to a global franchise, notable for its distinctive "red roof" architecture.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:58:00.767633288Z     '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:58:00.767637208Z     '*   **Innovations and Adaptations**: Introduced early internet ordering (PizzaNet) and innovative products like stuffed crust pizza. The chain has evolved through various restaurant formats and international menu localization.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:58:00.767639088Z     '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:58:00.767641418Z     '*   **Corporate Evolution**: Originally a family-run business, Pizza Hut became part of PepsiCo before being spun off into Yum! Brands, its current parent company.\n' +
2025-11-08T01:58:00.767643168Z     '\n' +
2025-11-08T01:58:00.767656649Z     '*   **Brand Identity and Marketing**: Characterized by its iconic red roof logo and has utilized diverse marketing strategies, including celebrity endorsements and sponsorships, and even a temporary "Pasta Hut" rebranding.'
